FeedItems.Summary:
co-authored by Scott Bommarito
At Microsoft, using the latest and secure encryption techniques is very important to us to ensure the security and privacy of our customers. TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1,...

FeedItems.Summary: We are excited to announce that nuget.org now supports package deprecation. This has been a long standing ask that will help the ecosystem use supported packages. As a package publisher on nuget.org,...

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[2020-07-21] Deployment" (#8117) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
⚠ This deployment has been postponed to July 27th, 2020.

# Gallery

Changes:
* Replace advisory permalink workaround with GitHub advisory permalink field (#8088)
* Made a test permalink a more realistic URL (#8108)
* Use OPTIMIZE FOR UNKNOWN for dependents queries (#8112)
* Add sorting and filtering UI to Gallery (#8105)
* Clean Elmah (#7962)
* Fix filter button alignment on small screens for Advanced Search panel (#8113)
* Merge pull request #8109 from NuGet/3268-Gallery-DB-schema
* Revert "Use protected configuration provider instead of reflection (#8124)

Progress:
* [x] Merge RI: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/8125
* [x] Release: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_releaseProgress?_a=release-pipeline-progress&releaseId=756011
* [x] DEV [DB migration](https://dev.azure.com/devdiv/DevDiv/_releaseProgress?_a=release-pipeline-progress&releaseId=754029)
* [x] DEV
* [x] INT [DB migration](https://dev.azure.com/devdiv/DevDiv/_releaseProgress?_a=release-pipeline-progress&releaseId=755996)
* [x] INT
* [x] PROD [DB migration](https://dev.azure.com/devdiv/DevDiv/_releaseProgress?_a=release-pipeline-progress&releaseId=755996)
* [x] PROD

# db2catalog

Changes:
* Remove extraneous property from vulnerabilities in catalog leaves (https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Services.Metadata/pull/809)

Release: https://dev.azure.com/devdiv/DevDiv/_releaseProgress?_a=release-pipeline-progress&releaseId=755785

Progress:
* [x] DEV
* [x] Merge RI: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Services.Metadata/pull/810
* [x] INT
* [x] PROD

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Advanced search] Update engineering documentation" (#8081) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
We need to update this documentation: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Services.Metadata/blob/master/src/NuGet.Services.SearchService/README.md

We should update V2 API reference to include the new `sortBy` values and `packageType` filter.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet Package Manager Browse tab search results are unordered and too broad" (#8131) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/1100552/nuget-package-manager-browse-tab-search-results-ar.html)._ --- In ther latest versions of Visual Studio (e.g., 16.6.1), searching for a package on the Browse tab of the NuGet Package Manager seems to be doing a full-text search and returning the thousands of results in a random order. For example, when I search for the Newtonsoft.Json package, the results that come back seem to contain either Newtonsoft or Json somewhere in the name, description, or dependencies(?). There seems to be no ordering for quality of match with the package name or anything that would make it reasonable to find the package to install it in my current project. For my example search, the Newtonsoft.Json package I was searching for was result number 656 in the list returned. This makes the tool virtually unusable and I have resorted to using nuget.org to find the packages/versions and manually editing the csproj files rather than wasting my time trying to find them in this tool. --- ### Original Comments #### Feedback Bot on 7/2/2020, 07:06 PM:

We have directed your feedback to the appropriate engineering team for further evaluation. The team will review the feedback and notify you about the next steps.

#### Feedback Bot on 7/28/2020, 05:10 PM:

This issue is currently being investigated. Our team will get back to you if either more information is needed, a workaround is available, or the issue is resolved.

#### Feedback Bot on 7/28/2020, 05:11 PM:

Thank you for sharing your feedback! Our teams prioritize action on product issues with broad customer impact. See details at: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/ide/report-a-problem?view=vs-2019#faq. In case you need answers to common questions or need assisted support, be sure to use https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/vs/support/. We’ll keep you posted on any updates to this feedback.

--- ### Original Solutions (no solutions)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Improve searching for nuget packages" (#8130) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/idea/1021643/improve-searching-for-nuget-packages.html)._ --- I don't know whether there is a limitation with nuget.org itself (the website is similarly basic) but searching for a nuget package in Visual Studio could be significantly improved if the search box treated space-separated strings as separate tokens and _ANDED_ these together when performing the search. For example, when entering "imm coll l" I'd want to see "System.Collections.Immutable" - NOT every package that contains _either_ "imm" or "coll". (I can't imagine why this appears to be the default behaviour...) Also, I'd like to be able to filter/rank based on number of downloads or "last updated" since there are a huge number of ancient packages which simply clutter up the result list --- ### Original Comments #### Feedback Bot on 5/8/2020, 01:34 AM: Thank you for taking the time to provide your suggestion. We will do some preliminary checks to make sure we can proceed further. We'll provide an update once the issue has been triaged by the product team. #### Peter Shaw on 5/15/2020, 04:27 AM:

In response to this tweet I posted:

https://twitter.com/shawty_ds/status/1261061801959178241

I'd also like to back this suggestion up.

I understand the need for some results to show up when a user is not sure what they are searching for, but right now as it stands, Visual Studio NuGet search IS UNUSABLE unless you know the EXACT spelling of the package your looking for.

Mores the point, the sub-string search is way too LAX, for example I do a search for "MapWinGis" (I Know this term is used in the package description, but is not the namespace name) and I get 100's of results, simply because many package names have "gi", "ma", "in" or "wi" ("wi" being an incredibly popular term, since we are on windows), showing these results is absolutely not helpful.

Filtering and ranking the results list is a really good idea, and improving the search to be more like say google search so we can say for example "MapWin" "GIS" and that will return packages that contain those exact phrases, or for example "Collections" -"Microsoft" will return anything with the exact phrase "Collections" in, but only if it does NOT contain the exact phrase "Microsoft"

As much as I dislike google these days, I have to admit the search operators they have and the way they work, actually make for a very powerful search syntax, to be really specific about what your searching for, having something similar in NuGet would be very, very helpful, especially when you have companies like "ThinkGeo" who have literally filled the first 10 pages of NuGet with their "free(but not actually free)" GIS library (Try a search for GIS in NuGet and see how long it takes before you see anything other than their offering), it would allow us to filter out bad actors like this that are using NuGet to drive sales, and focus on finding what we need fast.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Error 500 on initial account registration" (#8129) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### For issues regarding the NuGet client tools (the Visual Studio extension, NuGet.exe command line tool, etc.), file a bug on [NuGet Home](https://github.com/nuget/home/issues).

### Describe the bug
I've just compiled and modified the nugetgallery and uploaded to an azure web app. When I attempt to register for the first time I'm getting a 500, I feel I've done something wrong during the setup, but I'm not certain. Setting this up for POC so using limited resources in azure.

### To Reproduce
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. followed this document https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/blob/master/README.md
2. followed this document https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/blob/master/docs/Deploying/README.md
3, Site loads in browser

### Expected behavior
Was hoping to login

### Additional context
Azure App Plan is F1
Azure Sql DB is Basic

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Migrate to new Azure Search SDK" (#8128) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Consider migrating to [`Azure.Search.Documents`](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Azure.Search.Documents/) for improved performance and easier authentication.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Dependency Resolution Inconsistency" (#9861) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Expected: NuGet uses a nearest-wins approach to resolve conflicting dependencies. NuGet does not try to find a dependency that meets all constraints in the graph. That means, the dependency that is closer to the application in the dependency graph wins.
Actual: In the case below, this rule is violated. 

## Details about Problem

VS version (if appropriate):
2019

OS version:
Windows 10, 2004

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version:
No

dotnet version:
3.1

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

Let's assume we have 2 packages, C, and D. D comes in two versions and C takes a dependency on D. 
D 1.0.0
C 1.0.0 -> D 2.0.0

Let us construct an app that results in a classic package downgrade, by referencing both C an D:
- App
  - C 1.0.0
    - D 1.0.0
  - D 1.0.0

```
Detected package downgrade D from 2.0.0 to 1.0.0
  App -> C 1.0.0 -> D (>= 2.0.0)
  App -> D (>= 1.0.0)
```

Let us introduce two new dependencies, which we put in front of C and D:
A 1.0.0 -> C 1.0.0
B 1.0.0 -> D 1.0.0

We can now construct a new App that is identical to the first app, except the dependencies C and D are shifted down by one level. All we did is add a new first layer. The nearest wins rule should still hold, but we get the following instead:

- App
  - A 1.0.0
    - C 1.0.0
      - D 2.0.0 (! this version is farther away but wins)
  - B 1.0.0
    - D 2.0.0 (! package upgrade from 1.0.0 to 2.0.0, although it is closer to App)

There is no package downgrade error. Instead, D is promoted to 2.0.0. 

Screenshot:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/57002348/88838125-615fd400-d1d9-11ea-9e8f-53d2232a9c66.png)

Documentation:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/concepts/dependency-resolution

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGetFramework copy constructor does not create an equivalent frameworks" (#9849) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
This leads to ATF getting created with the wrong base framework and to an incorrect framework being used forrestore.

https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/e09cdc8a877737addb01eeb90d5ea2bd9433ac52/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Frameworks/AssetTargetFallbackFramework.cs#L52

Repros anytime you use ATF + framework with a platform.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Test Failure] VS gave a wrong constraint warning when there are no package constraint in the packages.config file after updating packages " (#9860) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet version: NuGet Client Dev\5.8.0.6753
VS Version: Master\30328.112
OS: Windows-10-Enterprise-RS5
## Detailed repro steps 
1.	Open VS, click “Create a new project” button and search template “ASP.NET Web Site (Razor v3)” in the filter.
2.	Create the project, open the PM UI of the project and go to the “Updates” tab.
3.	Check “select all packages” and click “Update” button.
4.	Build the project.
## Expected
There is no warning.
## Actual
There is a wrong constraint warning since there are no package constraint in the packages.config file as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/88785603-feb00d80-d1c3-11ea-8100-f983c7f91f5b.png)
## Note
1.	It didn’t repro on D16.7\30323.103 with Implicit NuGet Client Release-5.7.x\5.7.0.6726.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet does not respect TreatWarningsAsErrors" (#9858) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet restore is not respecting `<TargetWarningsAsErrors>`

VS: Version 16.8.0 Preview 1.0 [30323.161.master]

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

Given:

``` XML
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <OutputType>Exe</OutputType>
    <TargetFramework>netcoreapp3.1</TargetFramework>
    <TreatWarningsAsErrors>false</TreatWarningsAsErrors>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <ItemGroup>

    <PackageReference Include="Newtonsoft.Json" Version="9.0.1" />
    <PackageReference Include="Newtonsoft.Json.Bson" Version="1.0.2" />
    
  </ItemGroup>

</Project>

```

Expected: A single warning
Actual: A single error

```
Severity	Code	Description	Project	File	Line	Suppression State
Error	NU1605	Detected package downgrade: Newtonsoft.Json from 12.0.1 to 9.0.1. Reference the package directly from the project to select a different version. 
 ConsoleApp56 -> Newtonsoft.Json.Bson 1.0.2 -> Newtonsoft.Json (>= 12.0.1) 
 ConsoleApp56 -> Newtonsoft.Json (>= 9.0.1)	ConsoleApp56	C:\Users\davkean\source\repos\ConsoleApp56\ConsoleApp56\ConsoleApp56.csproj	1	


```

Looking at the assets file, its being marked as an error:

```
  "logs": [
    {
      "code": "NU1605",
      "level": "Error",
      "message": "Detected package downgrade: Newtonsoft.Json from 12.0.1 to 9.0.1. Reference the package directly from the project to select a different version. \r\n ConsoleApp56 -> Newtonsoft.Json.Bson 1.0.2 -> Newtonsoft.Json (>= 12.0.1) \r\n ConsoleApp56 -> Newtonsoft.Json (>= 9.0.1)",
      "libraryId": "Newtonsoft.Json",
      "targetGraphs": [
        ".NETCoreApp,Version=v3.1"
      ]
    }
```
...

## Other suggested things

### Verbose Logs

Please include verbose logs (NuGet.exe <COMMAND> -verbosity detailed | dotnet.exe <COMMAND> --verbosity diag | etc...)

### Sample Project

Very helpful if you can zip a project and paste into this issue!

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Cleaning up old binding redirects" (#9857) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/idea/1092773/cleaning-up-old-binding-redirects.html)._

---
Over time the config files of my solution got a lot of obsolete binding redirects. To clean them up I had to manually remove the existing redirects and then run on the nuget powershell the command Add-BindingRedirect

wanting to automate the process for all my projects in the solution, I found the code here very helpful
https://martowen.com/2018/09/12/refreshing-net-assembly-binding-redirects-in-a-visual-studio-solution/

Please add to the nuget powershell a command like Remove-BindingRedirect in the URL above so this can be done within VS built-in commands and not rely on 3rd party code

Another option would be to enhance the Add-BindingRedirect command with a parameter that will instruct it to remove all existing redirects before executing

---
### Original Comments

#### Feedback Bot on 6/27/2020, 11:52 PM: 

Thank you for taking the time to provide your suggestion.  We will do some preliminary checks to make sure we can proceed further.  We'll provide an update once the issue has been triaged by the product team.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Add an option to "GenerateNuspecOnBuild"" (#9856) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/idea/1070457/add-an-option-to-generatenuspeconbuild.html)._

---
Today, we have "GeneratePackageOnBuild" and we use it all the time. However, there are some occasions where we actually end up re-packing on the nuspec that gets put in obj/release. Given we know when these situations occur, it would be nice to not waste time creating the nuget and just generate a nuspec instead so we can pack later.

Thanks!

---
### Original Comments

#### Feedback Bot on 6/9/2020, 09:20 PM: 

Thank you for taking the time to provide your suggestion.  We will do some preliminary checks to make sure we can proceed further.  We'll provide an update once the issue has been triaged by the product team.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Group Nuget libraries together" (#9854) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/idea/887709/group-nuget-libraries-together.html)._ ---

Nuget libraries listed in the nuget manager should be grouped automatically using the name.

Example, Humanizer has a ton of libraries supporting different languages. So you have a bunch of packages that are names Humanizer.Core.af, Humanizer.Core.ar, Humanizer.Core.bg, etc.

It would be nice to save on scrolling to group all these packages together under 1 item.

--- ### Original Comments #### Donny Velazquez on 1/16/2020, 00:53 PM:

Group them under Humanizer.

#### Feedback Bot on 1/16/2020, 10:45 PM: Thank you for taking the time to provide your suggestion. We will do some preliminary checks to make sure we can proceed further. We'll provide an update once the issue has been triaged by the product team. #### Karan Nandwani [MSFT] on 1/21/2020, 04:50 PM:

Your suggestion has been queued up for prioritization. Feature suggestions are prioritized based on the value to our broader developer community and the product roadmap. We may not be able to pursue this one immediately, but we will continue to monitor it up to 90 days for community input.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "A simpler way to pack debug and release dlls inside a nuget package" (#9853) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/idea/1120708/a-simpler-way-to-pack-debug-and-release-dlls-insid.html)._ ---

My idea is to have inside the nuget package both debug version and release version of the package, this way, when the project is running on debug mode, it uses the debug dlls, and source link, and many other features to improve development.

and when I publish my project, as release, it uses the release version of the library, this way I would get most performance features, and all the benefits to use in production, with transparency to all developers.

StackOverflow - Nuget packages with both debug and release

--- ### Original Comments #### Feedback Bot on 7/21/2020, 08:15 PM: Thank you for taking the time to provide your suggestion.  We will do some preliminary checks to make sure we can proceed further.  We'll provide an update once the issue has been triaged by the product team.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "CVE-2020-1340 - NuGet Gallery Spoofing Vulnerability" (#45) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
A spoofing vulnerability exists when the NuGet Gallery does not properly sanitize input on package metadata values. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerability could perform cross-site scripting attacks and run scripts in the security context of the user viewing the malicious content.

To exploit this vulnerability, an attacker with permissions to upload packages could publish specially crafted content on a gallery page.

The security update addresses the vulnerability by correcting how NuGet Gallery sanitizes input.

**MSRC Security Guidance:** [CVE-2020-1340](https://portal.msrc.microsoft.com/en-US/security-guidance/advisory/CVE-2020-1340)
**Security Update:** [v2020.06.09](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/releases/tag/v2020.06.09)
